thread.title_full: MLB approves dugout signal for intentional walk in 2017: report

author: JAKE BECKER
title: MLB approves dugout signal for intentional walk in 2017: report
text:
43 PM 
The four-pitch intentional walk can take a hike. 
In an effort to improve the game’s pace of play, Major League Baseball approved a change to the intentional walk rule on Tuesday, ditching the drawn-out, traditional format for a dugout signal, sources told ESPN. 
The league and the players’ union agreed to the change, which will reportedly take effect at the start of the 2017 season. 
The new rule will allow a team to signal to the umpire its decision to walk a batter, rather than forcing a pitcher to toss four pitches outside the strike zone.

There were 932 intentional walks over 2,427 games last season, or one every 2.6 games, meaning the impact on pace of play would be smaller than some of the league's other proposals that have yet to be implemented. 
Commissioner Rob Manfred has discussed the idea of adding a 20-second pitch clock that has already been used in the minor leagues. He has also hinted at limiting the use of relievers, raising the low-end of the strike zone, and putting a runner on second base in extra innings. Tags:
